subject: Re: [junit] tests for a queue class?
msgSnippet: Well, unit testing really requires having an implementation, so let s assume one: import java.util.LinkedList; /** A trivial and incomplete FIFO Queue class. *
messageBody:
Well, unit testing really requires having an implementation, so let's
assume one:

import java.util.LinkedList;

/** A trivial and incomplete FIFO Queue class.
* @author Robert Sartin
* @version 1.1
*/
public class Queue {
LinkedList queue = new LinkedList();

/** Construct an empty Queue. */
public Queue() {
}

/** Remove and return first item from a Queue that has an item.
* @return the Object that was at the front of the Queue
*/
public Object remove() {
return queue.removeFirst();
}

/** Add an Object to the end of the Queue.
* @param o the Object to add
*/
public void add(Object o) {
queue.addLast(o);
}

/** Query if Queue is empty.
* @return true if the Queue is empty
*/
public boolean isEmpty() {
return 0 == queue.size();
}
}

and a quickie TestCase for it:

import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;

public class QueueTest extends TestCase {
public QueueTest(String name) {
super(name);
}

public static Test suite() {
return new TestSuite(QueueTest.class);
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
}

/** Verify Queue is empty when created. */
public void testEmptyOnCreation() {
Queue qut = new Queue();
assert(qut.isEmpty());
}

/** Verify Queue can have single item added and
* it is returned on remove.
*/
public void testAddThenRemove() {
Queue qut = new Queue();
Object foo = new Object();
qut.add(foo);

assertSame(foo, qut.remove());
assert(qut.isEmpty());
}

/** Verify Queue can have multiple items added and
* they are returned in FIFO order. Verify with two
* simple interleavings of add/remove.
*/
public void testFiFo() {
Queue qut = new Queue();
Object foo1 = new Object();
Object foo2 = new Object();
Object foo3 = new Object();
Object foo4 = new Object();

qut.add(foo1);
qut.add(foo2);
assertSame(foo1, qut.remove());
assertSame(foo2, qut.remove());
assert(qut.isEmpty());

qut.add(foo3);
assertSame(foo3, qut.remove());
assert(qut.isEmpty());
qut.add(foo4);
assertSame(foo4, qut.remove());
assert(qut.isEmpty());
}
}

It seems to test everything that could possibly break. Of course, now
that I've said that someone will point out some defects....

Note the missing tests:

- nothing to try to "overflow" a Queue since I didn't define what that
would mean or how it would happen. [In fact, it doesn't have limits
other than available heap.] A BoundedQueue would have test on those
aspects.

- nothing to verify thread safety since I did not explicitly say it was
thread safe. [In fact, it is not thread safe.] A ThreadSafeQueue would
have tests on those aspects.

- nothing to verify what happens when I remove from an empty Queue
since I did not specify what should happen. [In fact, it will throw
NoSuchElementException, but this wasn't specified.] Personally, if it
were really necessary I suppose I might test (and then maybe specify)
the NoSuchElementException.

Regards,

Rob
